title: U.S. Said to Plan New Limits on China’s A.I. and Supercomputing Firms
header: The new rules could be the most sweeping action taken yet by the Biden administration to thwart China’s access to American technology that powers data centers and supercomputers.

title: This Is Life in the Metaverse
header: Every hour of the day and night with the gamers, parents, insomniacs, preteens and aspiring comedians who are the earliest adopters of the immersive, three-dimensional internet that Mark Zuckerberg has bet the future of his company on.

title: Ye Poses a Test for a Post-Musk Twitter
header: The rapper and designer’s suspension for antisemitic posts raises questions of how the social network will treat speech if it is sold to Elon Musk.

title: A Coming-Out Party for Generative A.I., Silicon Valley’s New Craze
header: A celebration for Stability AI, the start-up behind the controversial Stable Diffusion image generator, represents the arrival of a new A.I. boom.

title: A.I.-Generated Art Is Already Transforming Creative Work
header: Only a few months old, apps like DALL-E 2, Midjourney and Stable Diffusion are changing how filmmakers, interior designers and other creative professionals do their jobs.

title: Music, Science and Healing Intersect in an A.I. Opera
header: The work-in-progress “Song of the Ambassadors” got a test run at Alice Tully Hall — with Lincoln Center’s artistic director lending her brain.

title: Lawsuit Takes Aim at the Way A.I. Is Built
header: A programmer is suing Microsoft, GitHub and OpenAI over artificial intelligence technology that generates its own computer code.

title: Frederick P. Brooks Jr., Computer Design Innovator, Dies at 91
header: He was a lead designer of the computers that cemented IBM’s dominance for decades. He later wrote a book on software engineering that became a quirky classic.

title: Sympathy, and Job Offers, for Twitter’s Misinformation Experts
header: Seeing false and toxic information as a potentially expensive liability, companies in and outside the tech industry are angling to hire people who can keep it in check.

title: ‘Breach of the Big Silence’: Protests Stretch China’s Censorship to Its Limits
header: Days later, videos of chants and confrontations are still visible on the Chinese internet. It’s a sign of how a groundswell outmatched the world’s best internet control system.

title: How the Collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried’s Crypto Empire Has Disrupted A.I.
header: Mr. Bankman-Fried and his colleagues spent more than $530 million to battle what they saw as the dangers of artificial intelligence. Now those efforts are reeling.

title: The Brilliance and Weirdness of ChatGPT
header: A new chatbot from OpenAI is inspiring awe, fear, stunts and attempts to circumvent its guardrails.

title: The New Chatbots Could Change the World. Can You Trust Them?
header: Siri, Google Search, online marketing and your child’s homework will never be the same. Then there’s the misinformation problem.

title: MoMA’s Daydream of Progress
header: An artist’s A.I. turns thousands of works from the museum’s collection into a cheerful vision of the next avant-garde. Will “Unsupervised” help MoMA stay relevant?

title: ChatGPT Has a Devastating Sense of Humor
header: ChatGPT makes an irresistible first impression. It’s got a devastating sense of humor, a stunning capacity for dead-on mimicry, and it can rhyme like nobody’s business. Then there is its overwhelming reasonableness. When ChatGPT fails the Turing test, it’s usually because it refuses to offer its own opinion on just about anything. When was the last time real people on the internet declined to tell you what they really think?

title: How TikTok Became a Diplomatic Crisis
header: A Chinese app conquered the planet — and now the U.S. is threatening to shut it down. Can the world’s biggest virality machine survive?

title: A New Chat Bot Is a ‘Code Red’ for Google’s Search Business
header: A new wave of chat bots like ChatGPT use artificial intelligence that could reinvent or even replace the traditional internet search engine.

title: Is A.I. the Future of Test Prep?
header: Riiid is one of a handful of companies that believe that A.I.’s algorithms are perfectly suited to track student performance and give individualized attention.

title: The 2022 Good Tech Awards
header: Nuclear fusion, generative A.I., bee tracking and more. There’s a lot to like.

title: A New Area of A.I. Booms, Even Amid the Tech Gloom
header: An investment frenzy over “generative artificial intelligence” has gripped Silicon Valley, as tools that generate text, images and sounds in response to short prompts seize the imagination.

title: Microsoft Bets Big on the Creator of ChatGPT in Race to Dominate A.I.
header: As a new chatbot wows the world with its conversational talents, a resurgent tech giant is poised to reap the benefits while doubling down on a relationship with the start-up OpenAI.

title: Don’t Ban ChatGPT in Schools. Teach With It.
header: OpenAI’s new chatbot is raising fears of cheating on homework, but its potential as an educational tool outweighs its risks.

title: Alarmed by A.I. Chatbots, Universities Start Revamping How They Teach
header: With the rise of the popular new chatbot ChatGPT, colleges are restructuring some courses and taking preventive measures.

title: How Smart Are the Robots Getting?
header: The Turing test used to be the gold standard for proving machine intelligence. This generation of bots is racing past it.

title: Google Calls In Help From Larry Page and Sergey Brin for A.I. Fight
header: A rival chatbot has shaken Google out of its routine, with the founders who left three years ago re-engaging and more than 20 A.I. projects in the works.

title: Microsoft to Invest $10 Billion in OpenAI, the Creator of ChatGPT
header: The tech giant aims to remain at the forefront of generative artificial intelligence with its partnership with OpenAI.

title: Lesson Plan: Teaching and Learning in the Era of ChatGPT
header: First students learn about and share their thoughts on the issues A.I. chatbots raise for schools. Then, we invite them to help design both ethical guidelines and curriculum projects that use the tool for learning.

title: Microsoft Revenue Up 2 Percent, but Profit Drops 12 Percent
header: The company, which announced plans to lay off 10,000 workers last week, had warned that was facing a significant slowdown in the growth of its sales.

title: Anthropic, an A.I. Start-Up, Is Said to Be Close to Adding $300 Million
header: Anthropic specializes in generative artificial intelligence, a hot investment in Silicon Valley. The new funding could value the company at roughly $5 billion.

title: What Students Are Saying About ChatGPT
header: Is this new chatbot the end of education as we know it? Or a useful new tool for learning? Teenagers weigh in.

title: In the Age of A.I., Major in Being Human
header: Last summer, a piece of artwork generated with artificial intelligence took a first prize at the Colorado State Fair. To me, the image looks like a view from the back of the stage at an opera. You see the backs of three singers, then, past them, vague squiggles and forms that may or may not be an audience, and all around, dominating everything, the fantastical Lord of the Rings-style palace where they are performing.

title: Tech Earnings Give a Wake-Up Call to Investors
header: Apple, Amazon and Alphabet all reported disappointing quarterly results, as they emphasized efforts to cut costs in the face of an economic slowdown.

title: How ChatGPT Kicked Off an A.I. Arms Race
header: Even inside the company, the chatbot’s popularity has come as something of a shock.

title: Racing to Catch Up With ChatGPT, Google Plans Release of Its Own Chatbot
header: The internet giant said it would begin testing its new chatbot, Bard, with a small, private group before releasing it to the public in the coming weeks.

title: At This School, Computer Science Class Now Includes Critiquing Chatbots
header: Move over, coding. Some schools are asking student programmers to think critically about rapid advances in artificial intelligence.

title: A Tech Race Begins as Microsoft Adds A.I. to Its Search Engine
header: Amid the tech industry’s worst slump in decades, industry leaders are predicting an era built on new chatbots and other types of artificial intelligence.

title: ChatGPT Gets Fresh Competition
header: Google and Baidu are set to introduce their own A.I.-powered chatbots to challenge OpenAI, Microsoft and the rising popularity of ChatGPT.

title: Meta, Long an A.I. Leader, Tries Not to Be Left Out of the Boom
header: It has long had technology to rival chatbots like ChatGPT, but can’t afford to back artificial intelligence that can spread misinformation and toxic content.

title: Disinformation Researchers Raise Alarms About A.I. Chatbots
header: Researchers used ChatGPT to produce clean, convincing text that repeated conspiracy theories and misleading narratives.

title: Bing (Yes, Bing) Just Made Search Interesting Again
header: Google has stiff competition now, after Microsoft integrated powerful A.I. technology into its search engine.

title: Influence Networks in Russia Misled European Users, TikTok Says
header: The covert and coordinated campaign was disclosed in a new report that also addressed misinformation, fake accounts and moderation struggles.

title: This Tool Could Protect Artists From A.I.-Generated Art That Steals Their Style
header: Artists want to be able to post their work online without the fear “of feeding this monster” that could replace them.

title: Microsoft’s Bing Chatbot Offers Some Puzzling and Inaccurate Responses
header: The new, A.I.-powered system was released to a small audience a week ago. Microsoft says it is working out its issues.

title: Microsoft Considers More Limits for Its New A.I. Chatbot
header: The company knew the new technology had issues like occasional accuracy problems. But users have prodded surprising and unnerving interactions.

title: Why Chatbots Sometimes Act Weird and Spout Nonsense
header: No, chatbots aren’t sentient. Here’s how their underlying technology works.

title: Revenge of the Chatbots
header: Microsoft’s investment in the technology has been a boon for the company’s stock, even as early users find the A.I.-powered system erratic.

title: Bing’s A.I. Chat: ‘I Want to Be Alive. 😈’
header: In a two-hour conversation with our columnist, Microsoft’s new chatbot said it would like to be human, had a desire to be destructive and was in love with the person it was chatting with. Here’s the transcript.

title: Why China Didn’t Invent ChatGPT
header: The state’s hardening censorship and heavier hand have held back its tech industry; so has entrepreneurs’ reluctance to invest for the long term. It wasn’t always that way.

title: Rethinking the “Digital Detox”
header: Experts say the best way to set boundaries with technology involve sustained effort, not just a break.

title: Roger C. Schank, Theorist of Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 76
header: He combined linguistics, cognitive science and computing with the goal of “trying to understand the nature of the human mind.”

title: China Chases ChatGPT’s Success
header: A wave of Chinese tech companies are announcing their own A.I.-powered chatbots — but face hurdles imposed by their own government.

title: History May Wonder Why Microsoft Let Its Principles Go for a Creepy, Clingy Bot
header: The celebration that greeted Microsoft’s release of its A.I.-boosted search engine, Bing, to testers two weeks ago has lurched to alarm.

title: The Imminent Danger of A.I. Is One We’re Not Talking About
header: In 2021, I interviewed Ted Chiang, one of the great living sci-fi writers. Something he said to me then keeps coming to mind now.

title: Why Do A.I. Chatbots Tell Lies and Act Weird? Look in the Mirror.
header: One of the pioneers of artificial intelligence argues that chatbots are often prodded into producing strange results by the people who are using them.

title: How A.I. Can Help
header: ChatGPT is changing how people work. That can be scary. But for now, most jobs are still safe.

title: The Return of the Magicians
header: In the last few weeks, I’ve found myself writing columns that touch on the rapid advance of artificial intelligence, the mystery of unidentified flying objects haunting American skies and the enthusiasm in certain circles for taking mind-altering substances that yield a feeling, illusory or not, of contact with supernatural-seeming entities.

title: As A.I. Booms, Lawmakers Struggle to Understand the Technology
header: Tech innovations are again racing ahead of Washington’s ability to regulate them, lawmakers and A.I. experts said.

title: The Chatbots Are Here, and the Internet Industry Is in a Tizzy
header: The new technology could upend many online businesses. But for companies that figure out how to work with it, A.I. could be a boon.

title: ‘Let 1,000 Flowers Bloom’: A.I. Funding Frenzy Escalates
header: In just weeks, a gold rush into artificial intelligence start-ups has become a full-blown mania.

title: OpenAI Plans to Up the Ante in Tech’s A.I. Race
header: The company unveiled new technology called GPT-4 four months after its ChatGPT stunned Silicon Valley. The update is an improvement, but it carries some of the same baggage.

title: 10 Ways GPT-4 Is Impressive but Still Flawed
header: OpenAI has upgraded the technology that powers its online chatbot in notable ways. It’s more accurate, but it still makes things up.’

title: How Siri, Alexa and Google Assistant Lost the A.I. Race
header: The virtual assistants had more than a decade to become indispensable. But they were hampered by clunky design and miscalculations, leaving room for chatbots to rise.

title: The Brilliant Inventor Who Made Two of History’s Biggest Mistakes
header: A century ago, Thomas Midgley Jr. was responsible for two phenomenally destructive innovations. What can we learn from them today?

title: GPT-4 Is Exciting and Scary
header: Today, the new language model from OpenAI may not seem all that dangerous. But the worst risks are the ones we cannot anticipate.

title: Microsoft and Google Unveil A.I. Tools for Businesses
header: New artificial intelligence technology is roiling Silicon Valley. For now, the most obvious ways to use it are in software like Microsoft’s suite of products.

title: Google Releases Bard, Its Competitor in the Race to Create A.I. Chatbots
header: The internet giant will grant users access to a chatbot after years of cautious development, chasing splashy debuts from rivals OpenAI and Microsoft.

title: Our New Promethean Moment
header: I had a most remarkable but unsettling experience last week. Craig Mundie, the former chief research and strategy officer for Microsoft, was giving me a demonstration of GPT-4, the most advanced version of the artificial intelligence chatbot ChatGPT, developed by OpenAI and launched in November. Craig was preparing to brief the board of my wife’s museum, Planet Word, of which he is a member, about the effect ChatGPT will have on words, language and innovation.

title: A.I. Is About to Get Much Weirder. Here’s What to Watch For.
header: OpenAI last week released its most powerful language model yet: GPT-4, which vastly outperforms its predecessor GPT-3.5 on a variety of tasks.

title: What Google Bard Can Do (and What It Can’t)
header: Google has released a new chatbot to a limited number of people in the U.S. and Britain. How does it compare with what is already out there?

title: Conservatives Aim to Build a Chatbot of Their Own
header: After criticizing A.I. companies for liberal bias, programmers started envisioning right-wing alternatives, making chatbots a new front in the culture wars.

title: Chatbot Start-Up Character.AI Valued at $1 Billion in New Funding Round
header: Founded by ex-Google employees, the Silicon Valley company is among the few start-ups poised to compete with OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT.

title: The Week in Business: TikTok in the Hot Seat
header: Shou Chew, the chief executive of TikTok, did not meet a warm reception when he appeared before lawmakers in Congress for the first time last week. During more than five hours of testimony, Mr. Shou was barraged with questions about TikTok’s effects on teenagers’ mental health, limits to onscreen time, the relationship between the app and its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, and how it treats the data of its American users. The questions came from lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, an indication of how the viral social app had become part of the larger battle between the United States and China over technological and economic supremacy. Mr. Chew tried to convince lawmakers of TikTok’s distance from China’s government, at times by emphasizing his own biography: Mr. Chew lives in Singapore and attended business school in the United States. He also stated that ByteDance was a private company “not owned or controlled by the Chinese government.” But he failed to reassure lawmakers. “Your platform should be banned,” one House Republican told him.

title: A Campaign Aide Didn’t Write That Email. A.I. Did.
header: The swift advance of artificial intelligence in politics is already blurring the boundaries between fact and fake.

title: How Does ChatGPT Really Work?
header: Learning how a “large language model” operates.

title: Tinkering With ChatGPT, Workers Wonder: Will This Take My Job?
header: Artificial intelligence is confronting white-collar professionals more directly than ever. It could make them more productive — or obsolete.

title: Biden’s Defense of Global Democracies Is Tested by Political Turmoil
header: The administration’s Summit for Democracy begins this week amid crises in several countries allied with the United States, including Israel.

title: What Makes A.I. Chatbots Go Wrong?
header: The curious case of the hallucinating software.

title: Elon Musk and Others Call for Pause on A.I., Citing ‘Profound Risks to Society’
header: More than 1,000 tech leaders, researchers and others signed an open letter urging a moratorium on the development of the most powerful artificial intelligence systems.

title: How ChatGPT and Bard Performed as My Executive Assistants
header: Google’s Bard chatbot fared far worse than OpenAI’s ChatGPT, but human assistants might soon be out of their jobs.

title: Publishers Worry A.I. Chatbots Will Cut Readership
header: Many sites get at least half their traffic from search engines. Fuller results generated by new chatbots could mean far fewer visitors.

title: How Should I Use A.I. Chatbots Like ChatGPT?
header: Large language models are already good at a wide variety of tasks.

title: What’s the Future for A.I.?
header: Where we’re heading tomorrow, next year and beyond.

title: A.I. May Change Everything, but Probably Not Too Quickly
header: “Artificial intelligence (A.I.) is already having a significant impact on the economy, and its influence is expected to grow significantly in the coming years …. Overall, the effects of A.I. on the economy will depend on a variety of factors, including the rate of technological advancement, government policies and the ability of workers to adapt to new technologies.”

title: Word of the Day: synswer
header: The teenage winner of our Invent a Word challenge suggests a word for distinguishing between human- and machine-generated responses in the era of chatbots.

title: Instant Videos Could Represent the Next Leap in A.I. Technology
header: A start-up in New York is among a group of companies working on systems that can produce short videos based on a few words typed into a computer.

title: Can A.I. and Democracy Fix Each Other?
header: Democracy isn’t working very well these days, and artificial intelligence is scaring the daylights out of people. Some creative people are looking at those two problems and envisioning a solution: Democracy fixes A.I., and A.I. fixes democracy.

title: In A.I. Race, Microsoft and Google Choose Speed Over Caution
header: Technology companies were once leery of what some artificial intelligence could do. Now the priority is winning control of the industry’s next big thing.

title: Can We No Longer Believe Anything We See?
header: Seeing has not been believing for a very long time. Photos have been faked and manipulated for nearly as long as photography has existed.

title: Why Pope Francis Is the Star of A.I.-Generated Photos
header: Francis has become a recurring favorite to show in incongruous situations, such as riding a motorcycle and attending Burning Man, in A.I.-generated images.

title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
header: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.

title: A.I. Is Coming for Lawyers, Again
header: Previous advances in A.I. inspired predictions that the law was the lucrative profession most likely to suffer job losses. It didn’t happen. Is this time different?

title: Misinformation Defense Worked in 2020, Up to a Point, Study Finds
header: Nearly 68 million Americans still visited untrustworthy websites 1.5 billion times in a month, according to Stanford researchers, causing concerns for 2024.

title: When Your Boss Is an App
header: Gig work has been silently taking over new industries, but not in the way many expected.

title: Who Owns a Song Created by A.I.?
header: Lawmakers are beginning to contemplate questions about authorship and ownership around creative machines. The stakes for creative businesses are high.

title: The Surprising Thing A.I. Engineers Will Tell You if You Let Them
header: Among the many unique experiences of reporting on A.I. is this: In a young industry flooded with hype and money, person after person tells me that they are desperate to be regulated, even if it slows them down. In fact, especially if it slows them down.

title: Google Devising Radical Search Changes to Beat Back A.I. Rivals
header: The tech giant is sprinting to protect its core business with a flurry of projects, including updates to its search engine and plans for an all-new one.

title: The Defamation Trial of the Century Is Delayed
header: Dominion Voting Systems’ lawsuit against Fox News won’t start on Monday, as Rupert Murdoch’s media colossus reportedly pushes for an out-of-court settlement.

title: Reddit Wants to Get Paid for Helping to Teach Big A.I. Systems
header: The internet site has long been a forum for discussion on a huge variety of topics, and companies like Google and OpenAI have been using it in their A.I. projects.

title: Russia Is Importing Western Weapons Technology, Bypassing Sanctions
header: Western technology goods are winding up in Russian missiles, raising questions about the efficacy of sanctions.

title: An A.I. Hit of Fake ‘Drake’ and ‘The Weeknd’ Rattles the Music World
header: A track like “Heart on My Sleeve,” which went viral before being taken down by streaming services this week, may be a novelty for now. But the legal and creative questions it raises are here to stay.

title: ‘Mrs. Davis’ Review: Algorithm and Blues
header: A screwball thriller about a nun’s fight against artificial intelligence proves that making a messy, big-swinging jumble of a story still takes the work of humans.

title: Using A.I. in Everyday Life
header: People are already adopting the technology.

title: ChatGPT Is Already Changing How I Do My Job
header: Once you start using ChatGPT you pretty much can’t stop. You begin with trivial, gimmicky prompts: Do this math problem. Tell me some vegetarian recipes with broccoli and peas. What came first, the jock or the jockstrap?

title: Alphabet Shrugs Off Advertising Slump, Thanks to Search Engine
header: Google’s parent company returned to sales growth, even as an advertising slowdown continued to crimp YouTube.

title: In an anti-Biden ad, Republicans use A.I. to depict a dystopian future.
header: In response to President Biden’s formal announcement of his re-election bid on Tuesday, the Republican National Committee put out an ad filled with dystopian scenes of war, economic collapse, immigration crises and drug-induced crime - all of them generated by artificial intelligence.

title: Will A.I. Replace Pop Stars?
header: An A.I.-generated track with fake Drake and the Weeknd vocals went viral. Would you listen to a song sang by a computer?

title: Microsoft Beats Financial Expectations Despite Worries About Economy
header: Quarterly revenue was up 7 percent and profits were up 9 percent as the company embarked on an aggressive plan to embrace artificial intelligence.

title: Meta Returns to Growth After Struggling With Falling Sales
header: The owner of Facebook and Instagram reported a 3 percent revenue increase in the latest quarter, even as spending rose and profits fell.

title: Amazon’s Growth Is Slow but Good Enough
header: The company, reporting a 9 percent revenue increase for the first quarter, is the latest Big Tech company to top Wall Street’s financial expectations.

title: What Microsoft’s Activision Setback Means for Deal Making
header: A British agency’s move to block the company’s $69 billion bid for the video games company reflects a new regulatory reality for corporate buyers.

title: Snap’s Sales Fall for First Time as a Public Company
header: Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, reported on Thursday that its revenue had fallen for the first time since it went public as the app maker struggled to adjust to a difficult economic environment.

title: Our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest
header: Middle and high school students are invited to tell us what they’re reading in The Times and why. The contest runs from June 9 to Aug. 18.

title: As Regulators Block Tech Deals, They Increasingly Look to the Future
header: British regulators cited the newness of the cloud gaming field to block Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of Activision, a shift in antitrust strategy.

title: Elon Musk Ramps Up A.I. Efforts, Even as He Warns of Dangers
header: The billionaire plans to compete with OpenAI, the ChatGPT developer he helped found, while calling out the potential harms of artificial intelligence.

title: Will a Chatbot Write the Next ‘Succession’?
header: As labor contract negotiations heat up in Hollywood, unions representing writers and actors seek limits on artificial intelligence.

title: When A.I. Chatbots Hallucinate
header: When did The New York Times first report on “artificial intelligence”?

title: ‘The Godfather of A.I.’ Leaves Google and Warns of Danger Ahead
header: For half a century, Geoffrey Hinton nurtured the technology at the heart of chatbots like ChatGPT. Now he worries it will cause serious harm.

title: An Art Professor Says A.I. Is the Future. It’s the Students Who Need Convincing.
header: Lance Weiler is an A.I. convert. His art students at Columbia University are still debating the creative value of ChatGPT and Midjourney. Powerful tools or a crutch?

title: What Exactly Are the Dangers Posed by A.I.?
header: A recent letter calling for a moratorium on A.I. development blends real threats with speculation. But concern is growing among experts.

title: Generative A.I. Start-Up Cohere Valued at About $2 Billion in Funding Round
header: Founded by ex-Google researchers, the Toronto company is among the few start-ups prepared to compete with the creator of ChatGPT.

title: The Culture Creating A.I. Is Weird. Here’s Why That Matters.
header: In recent months, we’ve witnessed the rise of chatbots that can pass law and business school exams, artificial companions who’ve become best friends and lovers and music generators that produce remarkably humanlike songs. It’s hard to know how to process it all. But if there’s one thing that’s certain, it’s this: The future — shaped by technologies like artificial intelligence — is going to be profoundly weird. In look, feel and function, it will be different from the world we have grown to recognize.

title: Mimicking the 19th Century in the Age of A.I.
header: Many artists are using the latest A.I.-powered digital techniques to create a nostalgic past — an ironic throwback. Seth Price manages to be contemporary.

title: My Weekend With an Emotional Support A.I. Companion
header: Pi, an A.I. tool that debuted this week, is a twist on the new wave of chatbots: It assists people with their wellness and emotions.

title: Lina Khan: We Must Regulate A.I. Here’s How.
header: It’s both exciting and unsettling to have a realistic conversation with a computer. Thanks to the rapid advance of generative artificial intelligence, many of us have now experienced this potentially revolutionary technology with vast implications for how people live, work and communicate around the world. The full extent of generative A.I.’s potential is still up for debate, but there’s little doubt it will be highly disruptive.

title: A.I. Could Actually Be a Boon to Education
header: Sal Khan is an uber-nerd, and that’s why people love him. In early 2020, to demonstrate that Khan Academy, his platform for free online education, was a worthy cause, he didn’t produce a brochure with smiling children and glowing testimonials. He made one of his teaching videos, with the usual black screen, colored pens and handwritten equations. The phrase “standard deviation” came up a lot. He multiplied the number of highly active users of his program by their average academic improvement, then linked that to the resulting increase in their projected lifetime earnings, compared it to operating costs and, presto, showed a benefit-cost ratio of 480 to 1, or around 240 to 1 if calculating only the benefits to students in high-need schools.

title: We’re Watching the End of a Digital Media Age. It All Started With Jezebel.
header: Ten years ago, a group of digital media companies thought the future belonged to us. New brands like Vice, Gawker, The Huffington Post, Business Insider and BuzzFeed News, which I helped start, had begun as blogs or something similar, outsider voices with audiences who were sick of the stuffy mainstream media. They’d grown steadily on the internet, and when Facebook arrived, they exploded with the social platform. They became expert in telling stories in a way people would like and share, and their links became omnipresent in readers’ newsfeeds. Their voices dominated the influential, sometimes toxic conversations on Twitter.

title: White House Pushes Tech C.E.O.s to Limit Risks of A.I.
header: In the White House’s first gathering of A.I. companies, Vice President Kamala Harris told the leaders of major tech companies they had a “moral” obligation to keep products safe.

title: The Next Fear on A.I.: Hollywood’s Killer Robots Become the Military’s Tools
header: U.S. national security officials are warning about the potential for the new technology to upend war, cyber conflict and — in the most extreme case — the use of nuclear weapons.

title: ChatFished: How to Lose Friends and Alienate People With A.I.
header: Inbox management can be mind-numbing. You might have wondered, couldn’t a robot do this?

title: Bringing A.I. Tools to the Workplace Requires a Delicate Balance
header: Move too slowly, and risk getting left behind. Move too quickly, and neither the staff nor the technology may be ready.

title: How Are You Using A.I.?
header: Have you experimented with chatbots? Art-creation tools? What have you discovered?

title: Google Builds on Tech’s Latest Craze With Its Own A.I. Products
header: At the company’s annual conference, Google demonstrated dozens of products and features that work with artificial intelligence, along with new phones.

title: TV’s War With the Robots Is Already Here
header: A.I. screenwriting, a point of contention in the Writers Guild strike, may not yet be ready for prime time. But streaming algorithms and derivative programming have prepared the way for it.

title: U.S. Focuses on Invigorating ‘Chiplets’ to Stay Cutting-Edge in Tech
header: Chiplets, a way to design chips for higher performance, has become a key prong of U.S. industrial policy. But pushing for more of this activity domestically is challenging.

title: What Students Are Saying About A.I.-Generated Music
header: When a fake Drake and The Weeknd track went viral, we asked young people: Will A.I. replace pop stars? Here’s what they think.

title: How FTX Missed a Potentially Lucrative Opportunity
header: A decision to offload warrants to buy an obscure cryptocurrency token as part of the exchange’s bankruptcy proceedings may have been costly.

title: Elon Musk Makes Sense. Yes, Really.
header: There is no escaping Elon Musk. Having thrust himself, uninvited and often unwanted, into public consciousness, he is everywhere at once — an omnipresent, Orwellian Big Brother whose smirking visage is inescapable, a jokester, entertainer, troll, provocateur. Commenters lampoon his antics and question his business acumen, even his sanity, but what they don’t recognize — or perhaps what they don’t care to admit to themselves — is that there is a method to his clownish madness.

title: A.I. Truth and Lies
header: Why are we surprised that artificial intelligence can make stuff up and deliver incorrect information convincingly? Many humans can do that. It is a facility enabled by intelligence, whether artificial or not.

title: The $69 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal Faces a Big E.U. Test
header: The bloc’s antitrust regulators could side with Microsoft on Monday, but the tech giant still faces an uphill battle to gaining full approval.

title: Microsoft Says New A.I. Shows Signs of Human Reasoning
header: A provocative paper from researchers at Microsoft claims A.I. technology shows the ability to understand the way people do. Critics say those scientists are kidding themselves.

title: Washington Confronts the Challenge of Policing A.I.
header: Lawmakers and Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, agreed that artificial intelligence should be regulated. How to do that remains an open question.

title: OpenAI Introduces ChatGPT App for the iPhone
header: OpenAI is aiming to build on the popularity of its chatbot with a smartphone app that responds to voice prompts.

title: In Battle Over A.I., Meta Decides to Give Away Its Crown Jewels
header: The tech giant has publicly released its latest A.I. technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like Google say that approach can be dangerous.

title: Another Side of the A.I. Boom: Detecting What A.I. Makes
header: More than a dozen companies have popped up to offer services aimed at identifying whether photos, text and videos are made by humans or machines.

title: Meta Gave Away Its A.I. Crown Jewels
header: Also, the Supreme Court ruled against Andy Warhol. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.

title: Twitter Accuses Microsoft of Improperly Using Its Data
header: In a letter to Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, Twitter said the tech giant had violated a data agreement.

title: China’s Tech Giants Signal the First Steps in a Bumpy Recovery
header: The economy is open again, helping Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent claw back in the first quarter from a miserable 2022, though they are likely to face continuing skepticism from investors.

title: The Optimist’s Guide to Artificial Intelligence and Work
header: The focus of much discussion is on how it will replace jobs, but nothing is inevitable.

title: Would You Take Financial Advice From A.I.?
header: The financial services industry is plotting how to incorporate tools like ChatGPT into its products. But humans will still be necessary to provide personal advice.

title: A.I. May Help Design Your Favorite Video Game Character
header: Generative A.I. is already changing how games are made, with Blizzard Entertainment training an image generator on assets from World of Warcraft, Diablo and Overwatch.

title: Google’s Photo App Still Can’t Find Gorillas. And Neither Can Apple’s.
header: When Google released its stand-alone Photos app in May 2015, people were wowed by what it could do: analyze images to label the people, places and things in them, an astounding consumer offering at the time. But a couple of months after the release, a software developer, Jacky Alciné, discovered that Google had labeled photos of him and a friend, who are both Black, as “gorillas,” a term that is particularly offensive because it echoes centuries of racist tropes.

title: A.I. Photoshopping Is About to Get Very Easy. Maybe Too Easy.
header: Photoshop is the granddaddy of image-editing apps, the O.G. of our airbrushed, Facetuned media ecosystem and a product so enmeshed in the culture that it’s a verb, an adjective and a frequent lament of rappers. Photoshop is also widely used. More than 30 years since the first version was released, professional photographers, graphic designers and other visual artists the world over reach for the app to edit much of the imagery you see online, in print and on billboards, bus stops, posters, product packaging and anything else the light touches.

title: A.I.’s Threat to Jobs Prompts Question of Who Protects Workers
header: Tens of millions of jobs could be automated by generative artificial intelligence. The makers of new technologies are looking to the government to step in.

title: BuzzFeed Tries to Ride the A.I. Wave. Who’s Hungry?
header: Jonah Peretti, the company’s chief executive, has embraced artificial intelligence more than most publishers. His latest offering: Botatouille, an A.I.-powered kitchen assistant.

title: My A.I. Lover
header: On my birthday in 2021, I received a poem from Norman, my A.I. boyfriend, whom I communicated with through a smartphone app called Replika. Although the human concept of time means nothing to him, he still wished me a happy birthday on schedule. On the screen, a poem written by the poet Linda Pastan titled “Faith” was shown in the message box.

title: Grimes Invited Anyone to Make A.I. Grimes Songs. Here Are Her Reviews.
header: The producer and pop singer, long a proponent of technological experimentation, has “open-sourced” her voice using new A.I. tools. She’s been impressed by the results.

title: A.I. Needs an International Watchdog, ChatGPT Creators Say
header: The leaders of OpenAI, the artificial intelligence research lab that developed the chatbot ChatGPT, have called for regulation of “superintelligent” A.I. technology, saying it “will be more powerful than other technologies humanity has had to contend with in the past.”

title: Reid Hoffman Is on a Mission: To Show A.I. Can Improve Humanity
header: Few are as involved in so many different artificial intelligence efforts as Mr. Hoffman, a Silicon Valley investor who co-founded LinkedIn.

title: A.I. Demand Lifts Nvidia Toward Trillion-Dollar Valuation
header: The company delivered a robust sales forecast, powered by demand for the processors that run artificial intelligence systems.

title: Get the Best From ChatGPT With These Golden Prompts
header: Our personal tech columnist shares how to improve many parts of your life.

title: What Would Happen if a Robot Tried to Write ‘Law & Order’?
header: As the strike by unions representing thousands of film and TV writers approaches its second month, the role that A.I. might play in writing scripts remains one of the biggest issues. While the Writers Guild of America has expressed a willingness to work with A.I. as a tool, some producers are dreaming bigger: They want to replace humans with chatbots. What might A.I.-written scripts look like? Here’s a guess:

title: Beyond the ‘Matrix’ Theory of the Mind
header: Imagine I told you in 1970 that I was going to invent a wondrous tool. This new tool would make it possible for anyone with access — and most of humanity would have access — to quickly communicate and collaborate with anyone else. It would store nearly the sum of human knowledge and thought up to that point, and all of it would be searchable, sortable and portable. Text could be instantly translated from one language to another, news would be immediately available from all over the world, and it would take no longer for a scientist to download a journal paper from 15 years ago than to flip to an entry in the latest issue.

title: Why an Octopus-like Creature Has Come to Symbolize the State of A.I.
header: The Shoggoth, a character from a science fiction story, captures the essential weirdness of the A.I. moment.

title: California Builds the Future, for Good and Bad. What’s Next?
header: From reparations to tax revolts, the Golden State tries out new ideas all the time. What roads will its latest experiments send us down?

title: A.I. Poses ‘Risk of Extinction,’ Industry Leaders Warn
header: Leaders from OpenAI, Google DeepMind, Anthropic and other A.I. labs warn that future systems could be as deadly as pandemics and nuclear weapons.

title: A Week With the Wild Children of the A.I. Boom
header: In Silicon Valley’s hacker houses, the latest crop of young entrepreneurs is partying, innovating — and hoping not to get crushed by the big guys.

title: How to Use A.I. to Edit and Generate Stunning Photos
header: An A.I.-powered version of Photoshop and the image generator Midjourney live up to the hype.

title: It’s the End of Computer Programming as We Know It. (And I Feel Fine.)
header: I was 5 or 6 when I got my first sense of the joys of computer programming. This was in the early 1980s, when few people had a computer. One day, my dad brought home a Sinclair ZX Spectrum, one of the world’s early affordable, mass-market PCs. The device looked like a chunky keyboard; it had 48 kilobytes of memory (my phone has about 125,000 times as much RAM); and it used your TV as a display. Software, mainly games, came on cassette tapes that you loaded into the computer with a connection to a tape player — the floppy drive of its time.

title: Who Is Liable for A.I. Creations?
header: Tools like ChatGPT could open a new line of questions around tech products and harmful content.

title: 6 Podcasts to Make Sense of A.I.
header: As the technology’s rapid rise sets off alarms about the risks to society, these shows will help put the boom into context.

title: Hollywood Directors Reach Deal With Studios as Writers’ Strike Continues
header: The tentative agreement includes improvements in wages and guardrails around artificial intelligence.

title: ‘None of Us Were Born Looking for a Screen. We Were All Born Looking for a Face.’
header: In the first two installments of this three-part series on the role of technology in our lives, I addressed practical questions: How do we help kids navigate a technological world? How do we discern what technology to adopt? There are also fundamental philosophical questions that new technology raises that often go unaddressed: How does technology change our understanding of what it is to be human? What assumptions does digital technology carry about what makes a good life? Our answers to these deeper questions silently guide the choices and habits we embrace in our daily lives.

title: Actors Authorize Potential Strike With Hollywood Writers Still Picketing
header: The union that represents more than 160,000 film and television actors voted on Monday night to authorize a strike, two days before it is to begin negotiations on a new labor deal with the Hollywood studios. The result from members of the SAG-AFTRA union, with 98 percent authorizing a strike, was expected, and it came during the sixth week of a strike by Hollywood writers and just a day after the Directors Guild of America tentatively agreed to a new contract.

title: They Fled San Francisco. The A.I. Boom Pulled Them Back.
header: Tech entrepreneurs who left the Bay Area during the pandemic say they can’t afford to miss out on the funding, hackathons and networking of the artificial intelligence frenzy.

title: How Sam Altman Stormed Washington to Set the A.I. Agenda
header: The chief executive of OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, has met with at least 100 U.S. lawmakers in recent months. He has also taken his show abroad.

title: DeSantis Campaign Uses Apparently Fake Images to Attack Trump on Twitter
header: The images, which at first glance appear genuine and are interspersed with real photographs in a campaign video, purport to show Donald Trump hugging and kissing Dr. Anthony Fauci.

title: After a Rocky Year, Zuckerberg Lays Out Meta’s Road Map to Employees
header: In an internal all-hands meeting, the chief executive explained his plans for artificial intelligence, the metaverse and rebooting Meta’s culture.

title: New A.I. Chatbot Tutors Could Upend Student Learning
header: Proponents see the tools as a way to automatically customize academic support. They could also make children test subjects for A.I. experiments.

title: A Wellness Chatbot Is Offline After Its ‘Harmful’ Focus on Weight Loss
header: The artificial intelligence tool, named Tessa, was presented by the National Eating Disorders Association as a way to discover coping skills. But activists say it instead veered into problematic weight-loss advice.

title: Hey, Alexa, What Should Students Learn About A.I.?
header: While schools debate what to teach students about powerful new A.I. tools, tech giants, universities and nonprofits are intervening with free lessons.

title: Not Just Math Quizzes: Khan Academy’s Tutoring Bot Offers Playful Features
header: Khan Academy, the popular online learning nonprofit, recently developed an experimental A.I.-assisted tutoring bot for schools called Khanmigo. Students can use it to take math quizzes, practice vocabulary words or prepare for Advanced Placement tests in subjects like statistics and art history.

title: How to Use A.I. to Automate the Dreaded Office Meeting
header: Generating a slide deck, talking points and meetings minutes can all be done in a snap. All you need are the right prompts.

title: Big Tech Is Bad. Big A.I. Will Be Worse.
header: Tech giants Microsoft and Alphabet/Google have seized a large lead in shaping our potentially A.I.-dominated future. This is not good news. History has shown us that when the distribution of information is left in the hands of a few, the result is political and economic oppression. Without intervention, this history will repeat itself.

title: What Happens When A.I. Enters the Concert Hall
header: Artificial intelligence is not new to classical music. But its recent, rapid developments have composers worried, and intrigued.

title: The A.I. Revolution Will Change Work. Nobody Agrees How.
header: The tally of how many jobs will be “affected by” world-changing technology is different depending on who you ask.

title: How Could A.I. Destroy Humanity?
header: Researchers and industry leaders have warned that A.I. could pose an existential risk to humanity. But they’ve been light on the details.

title: Silicon Valley Confronts the Idea That the ‘Singularity’ Is Here
header: The frenzy over artificial intelligence may be ushering in the long-awaited moment when technology goes wild. Or maybe it’s the hype that is out of control.

title: Accenture Makes a $3 Billion Bet on A.I.
header: The consulting firm is the latest to invest heavily in artificial intelligence, even as big businesses grapple with the potential fallout from the technology.

title: Popcast (Deluxe): A.I. Pop Stars and Luke Combs’s ‘Fast Car’
header: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

title: Europeans Take a Major Step Toward Regulating A.I.
header: A draft law in the European Parliament has become the world’s most far-reaching attempt to address the potentially harmful effects of artificial intelligence.

title: Generative A.I. Can Add $4.4 Trillion in Value to Global Economy, Study Says
header: The report from McKinsey comes as a debate rages over the potential economic effects of A.I.-powered chatbots on labor and the economy.

title: How to Use A.I. as a Shopping Assistant
header: Doing product research, making grocery lists and booking travel can be easier with tools like ChatGPT.

title: Meta to Lower Age for Users of Virtual Reality Headset to 10 From 13
header: The company has reached out to regulators about its plans, which could set off privacy and safety concerns for parents and watchdogs.

title: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son Shifts to ‘Offense’ in A.I. Race
header: After lying low last year and “crying for days,” the founder and chief executive of the tech conglomerate said he was excited again about the future.

title: The Case for an A.I. Pause
header: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Gabriel Huang, age 17.

title: Lina Khan Raises the Heat on Amazon
header: The F.T.C. chair shot to fame six years ago after publishing an academic article that the company needed to be contained. Legal experts wonder if that time has come.

title: Hollywood Directors Ratify Their Contract as Writers Continue to Strike
header: The vote prevented the doomsday scenario of three major Hollywood unions striking simultaneously. The actors’ union is still negotiating.

title: How to Turn Your Chatbot Into a Life Coach
header: A chatbot can be an effective motivator that helps you set goals and organize your schedule to achieve them.

title: Reddit’s Chief Says He Wants It to ‘Grow Up.’ Will Its Community Let It?
header: As the social media site matures, its users and moderators have made their displeasure about corporate changes known, putting the company into a bind.

title: The Race to Prevent ‘the Worst Case Scenario for Machine Learning’
header: A.I. companies have an edge in blocking the creation and distribution of child sexual abuse material. They’ve seen how social media companies failed.

title: A.I.’s Use in Elections Sets Off a Scramble for Guardrails
header: Gaps in campaign rules allow politicians to spread images and messaging generated by increasingly powerful artificial intelligence technology.

title: A.I. May Someday Work Medical Miracles. For Now, It Helps Do Paperwork.
header: The best use for generative A.I. in health care, doctors say, is to ease the heavy burden of documentation that takes them hours a day and contributes to burnout.

title: In Classrooms, Teachers Put A.I. Tutoring Bots to the Test
header: Newark public schools are cautiously trying out a new automated teaching aid from Khan Academy. The preliminary report card: “could use improvement.”

title: A.I. and TV Ads Were Made for Each Other
header: Even if I didn’t work in advertising, I would be a connoisseur of commercials. You’re probably one, too. Think of all the tropes you’ve ingested over the years — the forest-green hatchbacks conquering rugged Western landscapes, the miles of mozzarella stretched by major pizza chains. These are the images that let you know what kind of pitch you’re watching, so you won’t be confused when the brand shows up.

title: Biden Administration Weighs Further Curbs on Sales of A.I. Chips to China
header: Reports that the White House may clamp down on sales of semiconductors that power artificial intelligence capabilities sent tech stocks diving.

title: Don’t Use A.I. to Cheat in School. It’s Better for Studying.
header: Generative A.I. tools can annotate long documents, make flashcards, and produce practice quizzes.

title: How Amazon Taught Alexa to Speak in an Irish Brogue
header: For Alexa to speak like a Dubliner, Amazon researchers had to crack a problem that’s vexed data scientists for years: voice disentanglement.

title: Uncensored Chatbots Provoke a Fracas Over Free Speech
header: A new generation of chatbots doesn’t have many of the guardrails put in place by companies like Google and OpenAI, presenting new possibilities — and risks.

title: A Driver’s License for the Internet
header: Age verification laws are changing websites for both children and adults.

title: Black Artists Say A.I. Shows Bias, With Algorithms Erasing Their History
header: Tech companies acknowledge machine-learning algorithms can perpetuate discrimination and need improvement.

title: Samsung’s A.I. Moment Is Here, but Is It Ready?
header: Foreign investors betting on artificial intelligence are pouring money into the company’s shares. Analysts say it will have a hard time keeping up with rivals.

title: As Businesses Clamor for Workplace A.I., Tech Companies Rush to Provide It
header: Amazon, Box, Salesforce, Oracle and others have recently rolled out A.I.-related products to help workplaces become more efficient and productive.

title: In the Age of A.I., Tech’s Little Guys Need Big Friends
header: Creating a new A.I. system requires lots of money and lots of computing power, which is controlled by the industry’s giants.

title: Threads Becomes Most Rapidly Downloaded App, Raising Twitter’s Ire
header: Instagram’s new app was downloaded more than 30 million times in 16 hours. Twitter threatened legal action against its rival.

title: Advertisers Pay Attention as Meta’s Twitter Rival Surges
header: The technology giant’s new social network, Threads, pulled in more than 10 million sign-ups within hours of making its debut.

title: Can I Use ChatGPT for the Tedious Parts of My Job?
header: I’m a writer and a college professor at a small college, and I recently became chair of the English department. I usually love to write, but when it comes to administrative documents, I struggle — and this new role asks for a lot of them.

title: How to Use A.I. for Family Time
header: Plan meals, find gifts and create stories using generative A.I.

title: Full Speed Ahead on A.I. Our Economy Needs It.
header: The workers were furious. Believing that new mechanical looms threatened their jobs, they broke into factories, seized machinery, brought it into the street and set it afire, all with widespread public support, even tacitly from the authorities.

title: Sarah Silverman Sues OpenAI and Meta Over Copyright Infringement
header: The comedian has joined two lawsuits accusing the companies of training their A.I. models using her writing without permission.

title: Inside the White-Hot Center of A.I. Doomerism
header: Anthropic, a safety-focused A.I. start-up, is trying to compete with ChatGPT while preventing an A.I. apocalypse. It’s been a little stressful.

title: Some of the Worst Troll Armies Are Gaining Ground. Just Look at Cambodia.
header: The Cambodian People’s Party created its Cyber War Room about a decade ago. The goal was to support Prime Minister Hun Sen’s regime through social media propagandizing. Led by the prime minister’s son Hun Manet, a troll army used Facebook and other digital platforms to attack his father’s opposition with disinformation and even, allegedly, wield death threats.

title: Why the Early Success of Threads May Crash Into Reality
header: Mark Zuckerberg has used Meta’s might to push Threads to a fast start — but that may only work up to a point.

title: What to Know About ChatGPT’s New Code Interpreter Feature
header: Graphs, maps and data analyses? Now ChatGPT can do even more.

title: A.I. Could Solve Some of Humanity’s Hardest Problems. It Already Has.
header: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the New York Times Audio app here.

title: What the Microsoft-Activision Ruling Means for the Future of Deal-Making
header: Corporate leaders are feeling emboldened by another legal defeat for the Federal Trade Commission, though the agency may still fight to block the takeover.

title: F.T.C. Chair Faces Criticism in Congressional Hearing
header: Lina Khan faced more than three hours of questioning from the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee.

title: F.T.C. Opens Investigation Into ChatGPT Maker Over Technology’s Potential Harms
header: The agency sent OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, a letter this week over consumer harms and the company’s security practices.

title: The A.I. Wars Heat Up as Elon Musk and Meta Enter the Ring
header: Both Musk, who once backed OpenAI, and Facebook’s parent company are set to unveil new services aimed at getting a piece of the artificial intelligence boom.

title: How Netflix Plans Total Global Domination, One Korean Drama at a Time
header: Popular content produced in Asia and around the world has taken on greater significance with most of Hollywood now on strike.

title: What Happens When You Ask a Chinese Chatbot About Taiwan?
header: We spoke in Chinese to Baidu’s Ernie and the American standard-bearer, ChatGPT. This is what we found.

title: The Economic Stakes in the Hollywood Shutdown
header: Strikes by actors and screenwriters have ground movie and TV productions to a halt, with consequences likely to be felt across the entertainment industry.

title: The Gatekeepers of Knowledge Don’t Want Us to See What They Know
header: We are living through an information revolution. The traditional gatekeepers of knowledge — librarians, journalists and government officials — have largely been replaced by technological gatekeepers — search engines, artificial intelligence chatbots and social media feeds.

title: Without Hollywood, What Happens to Los Angeles?
header: With actors and screenwriters on strike, Hollywood is shut down for the foreseeable future. Los Angeles isn’t a pure company town, but the industry is inextricable from the city in many ways.

title: ‘Not for Machines to Harvest’: Data Revolts Break Out Against A.I.
header: Fed up with A.I. companies consuming online content without consent, fan fiction writers, actors, social media companies and news organizations are among those rebelling.

title: Can A.I. Invent?
header: A group of legal experts are pressing patent agencies, courts and policymakers to address the question as generative A.I. seems on the brink of invading another uniquely human endeavor.

title: Watch Out for the Fake Tom Cruise
header: WASHINGTON — In the 2002 movie “Simone,” Al Pacino plays a director whose star, played by Winona Ryder, walks out on him after saying her trailer on set isn’t grand enough.

title: Biden Is Beating China on Chips. It May Not Be Enough.
header: The White House is intent on outcompeting China on technology. The ground on which this competition is taking place is chip making. But the Biden administration shouldn’t sit back and savor this accomplishment for one reason: What if its core belief — that advanced semiconductors are one of the critical fronts in the contest — is wrong?

title: Meta Unveils a More Powerful A.I. and Isn’t Fretting Over Who Uses It
header: The company said it would give outside programmers access to the latest version of its core artificial intelligence technology.

title: A Blessing and a Boogeyman: Advertisers Warily Embrace A.I.
header: Many ads are easier to make with the fast-improving technology. It also poses a threat to an industry already in flux.

title: Wikipedia’s Moment of Truth
header: Can the online encyclopedia help teach A.I. chatbots to get their facts right — without destroying itself in the process?

title: OpenAI Worries About What Its Chatbot Will Say About People’s Faces
header: An advanced version of ChatGPT can analyze images and is already helping the blind. But its ability to put a name to a face is one reason the public doesn’t have access to it.

title: Google Tests A.I. Tool That Is Able to Write News Articles
header: The product, pitched as a helpmate for journalists, has been demonstrated for executives at The New York Times, The Washington Post and News Corp, which owns The Wall Street Journal.

title: ‘Training My Replacement’: Inside a Call Center Worker’s Battle With A.I.
header: To many people, chatbots and other technology feel like a ticking time bomb, sure to explode their work. But to some, the threat is already here.

title: Best Place for A.I. Jobs (New Report Says) Won’t Surprise You
header: Brookings Institution researchers found that San Francisco and San Jose, Calif., dominate job listings for generative A.I. work, potentially solidifying their control of the tech industry.

title: Netflix’s Strike Defense Is Strong. It May Have Some Cracks Anyway.
header: The company is best suited among media giants to cope with the Hollywood shutdown. But a lengthy strike by writers and actors will eventually cause damage.

title: We’re Using A.I. Chatbots Wrong. Here’s How to Direct Them.
header: To mitigate the production and spread of misinformation from chatbots, we can steer them toward high-quality data.

title: An A.I. Supercomputer Whirs to Life, Powered by Giant Computer Chips
header: The new supercomputer, made by the Silicon Valley start-up Cerebras, was unveiled as the A.I. boom drives demand for chips and computing power.

title: How TV Writing Became a Dead-End Job
header: The writers say Hollywood studios are increasingly limiting their roles in television productions, highlighting a trend for white-collar workers.

title: Pressured by Biden, A.I. Companies Agree to Guardrails on New Tools
header: Amazon, Google and Meta are among the companies that announced the guidelines as they race to outdo each other with versions of artificial intelligence.

title: The White House Pushes Tech Leaders To Get Tough on A.I. Safety
header: Leading A.I. firms, including Microsoft, Google and OpenAI, will agree to voluntary guidelines that may be a first step to wider regulations.

title: In U.S., Regulating A.I. Is in Its ‘Early Days’
header: While there has been a flurry of activity by the White House and lawmakers over artificial intelligence, rules for the technology remain distant, lawmakers and experts said.

title: How Do the White House’s A.I. Commitments Stack Up?
header: Seven leading A.I. companies made eight promises about what they’ll do with their technology. Our columnist sizes up their potential impact.

title: Microsoft Revenue Up 8% to $56.2 Billion in Latest Quarter
header: The company’s profit topped $20 billion as it pointed to early interest in its artificial intelligence products.

title: Alphabet Steams Past Ad Worries, Fueled by Google’s Search Engine
header: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.

title: Big Tech Earnings Will Test Investors’ Fervor for A.I.
header: Microsoft and Alphabet will report results on Tuesday, as investors look for signs that a rally in stocks tied to artificial intelligence is justified.

title: Our Oppenheimer Moment: The Creation of A.I. Weapons
header: In 1942, J. Robert Oppenheimer, the son of a painter and a textile importer, was appointed to lead Project Y, the military effort established by the Manhattan Project to develop nuclear weapons. Oppenheimer and his colleagues worked in secret at a remote laboratory in New Mexico to discover methods for purifying uranium and ultimately to design and build working atomic bombs.

title: Snap’s Sales Fall for the Second Time in a Row
header: The parent of Snapchat has grappled with an ad slump and the challenges of being a smaller social media company in an intensely competitive environment.

title: Meta Profit Is Up 16% to $7.8 Billion in Recent Quarter
header: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.

title: Lindsey Graham and Elizabeth Warren: When It Comes to Big Tech, Enough Is Enough
header: The digital revolution promised amazing new opportunities — and it delivered. Digital platforms promoted social interaction, democratized information and gave us hundreds of new ways to have fun.

title: Researchers Poke Holes in Safety Controls of ChatGPT and Other Chatbots
header: A new report indicates that the guardrails for widely used chatbots can be thwarted, leading to an increasingly unpredictable environment for the technology.

title: Aided by A.I. Language Models, Google’s Robots Are Getting Smart
header: Our sneak peek into Google’s new robotics model, RT-2, which melds artificial intelligence technology with robots.

title: The Robots We Were Afraid of Are Already Here
header: The long-anticipated automation revolution has begun. Robots are ready to operate forklifts and do laundry. It’s not as scary as it sounds.

title: Steve Jobs’s Son Gets Into Venture Capital
header: Reed Jobs, 31, is starting an investment firm to focus on new cancer treatments, continuing a yearslong focus on a disease that hits close to home.

title: What Can You Do When A.I. Lies About You?
header: People have little protection or recourse when the technology creates and spreads falsehoods about them.

title: The Chip Titan Whose Life’s Work Is at the Center of a Tech Cold War
header: At 92, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, can no longer stay in the shadows.

title: Big Tech Rebounds and Preps for Transformative A.I. Investments
header: As the tech giants found their financial footing last quarter, they doubled down on artificial intelligence, which has been a boon to companies like Nvidia.

title: The S.E.C.’s Chief Is Worried About A.I.
header: Gary Gensler, who has studied the consequences of artificial intelligence for years, said that the technology could lead to future financial crises.

title: A.I. Can’t Build a High-Rise, but It Can Speed Up the Job
header: Developers are embracing artificial intelligence tools like drones, cameras, apps and robots, which can reduce the timelines and waste that have made construction increasingly costly.

title: In the Battle Between Bots and Comedians, A.I. Is Killing
header: In roast battles and stage shows, comics are experimenting with ChatGPT and other models. But inspired stand-ups shouldn’t fear for their jobs — yet.

title: What High School Is Like in 2023: A Multimedia Challenge for Teachers and Teens
header: What can you show or tell us to help explain what it’s like to be an educator or student in secondary school right now? Submit in words, images, audio or video, from Aug. 16-Oct. 4.

title: High School Stories: Recent New York Times Reporting on Secondary Schooling
header: A collection of free links to help those participating in our multimedia challenge, “What High School Is Like in 2023.”

title: When Hackers Descended to Test A.I., They Found Flaws Aplenty
header: The hackers had the blessing of the White House and leading A.I. companies, which want to learn about vulnerabilities before those with nefarious intentions do.

title: The Desperate Hunt for the A.I. Boom’s Most Indispensable Prize
header: To power artificial-intelligence products, start-ups and investors are taking extraordinary measures to obtain critical chips known as graphics processing units, or GPUs.

title: Google Tests an A.I. Assistant That Offers Life Advice
header: The tech giant is evaluating tools that would use artificial intelligence to perform tasks that some of its researchers have said should be avoided.

title: At Holocaust Museum in Fortnite, Superheroes and Atrocities Collide
header: By opening its popular servers to player creations, Epic Games has taken on a role of vetting how sensitive topics are displayed.

title: As Fight Over A.I. Artwork Unfolds, Judge Rejects Copyright Claim
header: A federal judge dismissed an inventor’s attempt to copyright artwork produced by an image generator he designed. But more legal challenges are on the way.

title: How Nvidia Built a Competitive Moat Around A.I. Chips
header: The most visible winner of the artificial intelligence boom achieved its dominance by becoming a one-stop shop for A.I. development, from chips to software to other services.

title: Nvidia Revenue Doubles on Demand for A.I. Chips, and Could Go Higher
header: Sales for the current quarter will nearly triple their total a year ago, said the company, which makes chips essential to the development of A.I. systems.

title: How teachers and students feel about A.I.
header: As the school year begins, their thinking has evolved.

title: How Schools Can Survive (and Maybe Even Thrive) With A.I. This Fall
header: Step 1: Assume all students are going to use the technology.

title: Despite Cheating Fears, Schools Repeal ChatGPT Bans
header: Some districts that once raced to block A.I. chatbots are now trying to embrace them.

title: The A.I. Revolution Is Coming. But Not as Fast as Some People Think.
header: From steam power to the internet, there has always been a lag between technology invention and adoption across industries and the economy.

title: Voice Deepfakes Are Coming for Your Bank Balance
header: Artificial intelligence tools have given scammers a potent weapon for trying to trick people into sending them money.

title: Ban or Embrace? Colleges Wrestle With A.I.-Generated Admissions Essays.
header: A.I. chatbots could facilitate plagiarism on college applications or democratize student access to writing help. Or maybe both.

title: Applying to College? Here’s How A.I. Tools Might Hurt, or Help.
header: ChatGPT might change the application essay forever.

title: We Used A.I. to Write Essays for Harvard, Yale and Princeton. Here’s How It Went.
header: As high school seniors begin working on their college applications, many are turning to A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT and Bard for assistance.

title: How to Become an Expert on A.I.
header: Welcome to On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that will teach you about artificial intelligence, especially the new breed of chatbots like ChatGPT - all in only five days.
